module.title: Regulations
module.description: FAA Part 107 rules and regulatory requirements for sUAS operations

lessons.title: General Regulations
objectives: Understand the applicability of 14 CFR Part 107 to sUAS operations
Define key terms: sUAS, Remote PIC, Visual Observer, Control Station
Know the 55-pound weight limit and what it includes

sections.title: Applicability of Part 107
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR Part 107 governs the **registration, certification, and operation** of civil small unmanned aircraft systems within the United States.

**Part 107 applies to:**

- Civil (non-military, non-public) small UAS operations in the NAS
- Any sUAS weighing **less than 55 pounds** at takeoff (including everything on board)
- Both commercial and non-commercial operations conducted under Part 107
- Airman certification (your Remote Pilot Certificate)

**Part 107 does NOT apply to:**

- **Recreational flying** under 49 U.S.C. §44809 (TRUST test)
- **Public aircraft operations** (government operations under a COA)
- Operations under Section 333 or §44807 exemptions
- sUAS with an airworthiness certificate operating under Part 91

## Why It Matters

This is the first question you should answer: "Does Part 107 apply to what I'm doing?" If you're flying commercially (real estate photos, inspections, mapping, delivery), this regulation governs you.

## What the Exam Tests

Expect questions like:
- "Under what regulation would a commercial drone operation fall?"
- "A drone weighing 52 lbs with a camera is used for real estate photography. What regulations apply?"
- "Which operations are NOT covered by Part 107?"

sections.title: Key Definitions
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR 107.3 defines the core terminology every remote pilot must know.

### Small Unmanned Aircraft

An unmanned aircraft weighing **less than 55 pounds on takeoff**, including everything on board or attached.

### Small Unmanned Aircraft System (sUAS)

The small unmanned aircraft **and its associated elements** — communication links, control components — required for safe operation.

> **Key Distinction:** The "aircraft" is just the flying machine. The "system" is the aircraft PLUS controller, data link, ground station, and display.

### Remote Pilot in Command (Remote PIC)

The person who holds a Remote Pilot Certificate with sUAS rating and has **final authority and responsibility** for the operation.

### Visual Observer (VO)

A person designated by the remote PIC to assist with see-and-avoid duties. VOs are **optional**, not required.

### Control Station

The interface (controller/tablet/GCS) used to control the flight path.

### Person Manipulating Flight Controls

Whoever is physically operating the sticks at any moment. May or may not be the Remote PIC.

## Why It Matters

These definitions establish the **chain of responsibility**. The Remote PIC holds final authority — even if someone else is flying the drone.

bogeyman.message: Aircraft vs. System is a favorite exam trap! The aircraft is just the drone. The sUAS includes the controller, data links, and everything needed to operate it.

sections.title: The 55-Pound Weight Limit
sections.content:
## What the Rule Says

The maximum takeoff weight for a small unmanned aircraft under Part 107 is **less than 55 pounds**, including:

- The aircraft itself
- All batteries
- All payload (cameras, sensors, cargo)
- Any attachments (parachute systems, lights)

## Common Traps

- If your drone weighs 48 lbs and you attach a 10 lb camera, that's 58 lbs — **no longer qualifies** under Part 107
- The weight is measured at **takeoff**, not empty weight
- Part 107 is not just for commercial ops — anyone can choose to fly under it

## Key Facts to Memorize

| Fact | Detail |
|---|---|
| Maximum takeoff weight | **< 55 lbs** (including all onboard equipment) |
| Governing regulation | **14 CFR Part 107** |
| Recreational alternative | 49 U.S.C. §44809 (TRUST test) |
| Public aircraft | Excluded — operate under COA |

lessons.title: Falsification and Accident Reporting
objectives: Know when accident reporting is required

sections.title: Falsification of Records
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR 107.5 makes it a **federal offense** to:

- Make or cause to be made any **fraudulent or intentionally false** record or report
- **Reproduce** for fraudulent purpose any certificate or authorization
- **Alter** any certificate, rating, authorization, record, or report

## The Consequences

Committing any of these acts is grounds for:

1. **Denial** of an application for a Remote Pilot Certificate
2. **Denial** of an application for a certificate of waiver
3. **Suspension or revocation** of any certificate or waiver
4. **Civil penalties** (fines)
5. Potential **criminal penalties**

## Why It Matters

The FAA takes integrity of records extremely seriously. Every accident report, maintenance log, and certificate exists to keep the NAS safe.

## Common Traps

- This covers records you "cause to be made," not just ones you personally create
- Even minor alterations count — changing a date is falsification
- The consequences are severe and can end your career as a remote pilot

sections.title: Accident Reporting Requirements
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

Under 14 CFR 107.9, the Remote PIC must report to the FAA within **10 calendar days** of any operation that results in:

1. **Serious injury** to any person (AIS Level 3+)
2. **Loss of consciousness** of any person
3. **Damage to any property** other than the sUAS exceeding **$500**

## The Reporting Process

Reports are submitted to the FAA's online reporting system and should include:
- Date, time, and location of the accident
- Description of the sUAS involved
- Description of the accident
- Injuries or property damage that occurred

## What the Exam Tests

This is one of the **most frequently tested** topics. Key points:

1. The **$500 threshold** applies to property OTHER than the drone
2. The deadline is **10 calendar days** (not business days)
3. Know what qualifies as a triggering event

bogeyman.message: The $500 threshold applies to property OTHER than your drone. If your $3,000 drone is destroyed but nothing else is damaged, there's nothing to report!

sections.title: Accident Reporting Scenarios
sections.content:
## Typical Exam Questions

**Scenario 1:** Your sUAS crashes into a parked car causing $600 in damage. The drone is destroyed ($1,200). No injuries.

→ **Report within 10 days.** Car damage exceeds $500; drone damage doesn't count.

**Scenario 2:** Your sUAS clips a tree and crashes. The $1,200 drone is totaled. No other damage, no injuries.

→ **No report required.** Damage to the sUAS itself is excluded.

**Scenario 3:** A bystander is hit by your sUAS and briefly loses consciousness but has no visible injuries.

→ **Yes, report it.** Loss of consciousness is a mandatory trigger regardless of visible injury.

## Key Facts to Memorize

| Detail | Value |
|---|---|
| Reporting deadline | **10 calendar days** |
| Property damage threshold | **> $500** (to property OTHER than the sUAS) |
| Injury trigger | **Serious injury** (AIS Level 3+) |
| Consciousness trigger | **Any loss of consciousness** |
| Drone damage | **Does NOT trigger reporting** |
| Report to | **FAA** |

bogeyman.message: 10 calendar days, not business days! If the accident happens on a Friday, day 10 is the Sunday a week and a half later.

sections.title: Inspection and Compliance
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR 107.7 establishes the FAA's authority to inspect your operation.

### Presentation of Documents

Upon request by the FAA, you must present:
- Your Remote Pilot Certificate with sUAS rating
- Any document, record, or report required under Part 107

### Testing and Inspection Authority

Upon request, you must allow the FAA to:
- Make any test or inspection of the sUAS
- Inspect any person involved in the operation
- Conduct any inspection to determine compliance

## Why It Matters

This is the legal basis for an FAA inspector approaching you in the field. **Refusing is a violation of Part 107.**

## Common Traps

- You **cannot refuse** an FAA inspection
- This covers more than just the drone — the FAA can inspect aircraft, your certificate, records, and you
- It's not just the PIC's obligation — VOs, owners, operators all must comply

sections.title: Multiple Category sUAS
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

A single sUAS can be eligible to operate under **more than one category** for operations over people (Categories 1–4). The same drone might qualify as Category 1 for one mission and Category 2 for another, depending on configuration.

**Critical Rule:** The Remote PIC must **not be able to inadvertently switch** between categories during flight.

## Why It Matters

Many commercial drones can be configured differently depending on the mission. A drone weighing 0.50 lbs with no payload (Category 1) might weigh 2 lbs with a camera attached (potentially Category 2 or 3).

## Key Facts

| Fact | Detail |
|---|---|
| Can one sUAS qualify for multiple categories? | **Yes** |
| What determines the category? | Configuration at time of operation |
| Key safety requirement | Cannot **inadvertently switch** categories during flight |

sections.title: Record Retention
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR 107.165 establishes record retention requirements.

### For Manufacturers (Category 2/3 Aircraft)

- Must retain all supporting information demonstrating compliance
- Retention period: **2 years after ceasing production** of that model

### For Declaration Submitters

- Must retain all detailed information submitted with the declaration
- Retention period: **2 years after submission date**

### For Means of Compliance (MoC) Submitters

- Must retain the detailed description of the means of compliance
- Retention period: **As long as the MoC remains FAA-accepted**

### For All Remote Pilots (Best Practices)

While not mandated, the FAA strongly recommends maintaining:
- Flight logs
- Maintenance records
- Preflight inspection records
- Incident/accident documentation

## Key Facts to Memorize

| Who | Retention Period |
|---|---|
| Manufacturers (Cat 2/3) | **2 years** after ceasing production |
| Declaration submitters | **2 years** after submission date |
| MoC submitters | **As long as MoC remains FAA-accepted** |

lessons.title: Remote Pilot Certification
objectives: Know eligibility requirements for Remote Pilot Certificate
Learn about waivers and their application process

sections.title: Certificate Eligibility
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

To obtain a Remote Pilot Certificate with sUAS rating, you must:

1. Be at least **16 years old** (exam can be taken at 14, but certificate not issued until 16)
2. Be able to **read, speak, write, and understand English**
3. Be in a physical and mental condition to safely operate an sUAS
4. Pass the initial aeronautical knowledge test
5. Be vetted by TSA

## Recency Requirements

To maintain currency, you must complete **recurrent training or testing every 24 calendar months**.

## What the Exam Tests

- Age requirements (16 to obtain, 14 to test)
- Recency period (24 calendar months)
- English language requirements

sections.title: Waivers
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

Many Part 107 rules can be waived if you demonstrate **equivalent safety**. Waivers are applied for through **FAA DroneZone**.

## Commonly Waivable Rules

- Night operations (before 2021 rule)
- Visual line of sight (VLOS)
- Altitude limitations
- Operations over people
- Multiple aircraft by single pilot

## The Waiver Process

1. Submit application through FAA DroneZone
2. Describe how you will maintain equivalent safety
3. Include operational procedures and risk mitigations
4. Wait for FAA review (can take weeks to months)

## Key Facts

- Waivers require demonstrating **equivalent safety**
- Some rules cannot be waived (e.g., registration requirements)
- Waivers have specific conditions that must be followed

lessons.title: Operations Over People and Remote ID
objectives: Understand the four categories for operations over people

sections.title: Operations Over People Categories
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

Operations over people are divided into four categories based on aircraft capabilities and risk:

### Category 1

- Weight: **≤ 0.55 lbs** (250 grams)
- No exposed rotating parts that could lacerate skin
- No Declaration of Compliance needed
- Can fly over people without further restrictions

### Category 2

- Weight: ≤ 0.55 lbs OR meets severity limit
- Has FAA-accepted **Declaration of Compliance (DoC)**
- Impact kinetic energy limits (11 ft-lbs)
- No exposed rotating parts that could lacerate skin

### Category 3

- Same requirements as Category 2
- **Cannot fly over open-air assemblies**
- Must be over closed/restricted sites OR people directly participating
- Impact kinetic energy limits (25 ft-lbs)

### Category 4

- Has an **airworthiness certificate** under Part 21
- Must operate within aircraft operating limitations
- Manufacturer specifies eligible operations

## Key Distinctions

| Category | Max Weight | DoC Required? | Open-Air Assemblies? |
|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | ≤ 0.55 lbs | No | Yes |
| 2 | Varies | Yes | Yes |
| 3 | Varies | Yes | **No** |
| 4 | Per certificate | N/A | Per limitations |

sections.title: Remote Identification
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

14 CFR Part 89 establishes Remote Identification requirements.

### Standard Remote ID

The sUAS broadcasts identification data directly from the drone, including:
- Drone ID (serial number or session ID)
- Drone location, altitude, and velocity
- Control station location
- Timestamp
- Emergency status

### Remote ID Broadcast Module

An add-on device for previously manufactured drones that broadcasts:
- Module serial number
- Drone location and altitude
- Takeoff location
- Timestamp

### FAA-Recognized Identification Areas (FRIAs)

Designated areas where drones without Remote ID can still operate.

## Why It Matters

Remote ID enables the FAA, law enforcement, and other authorities to identify drones in flight. All new drones must have Standard Remote ID built in.

## Key Facts

| Compliance Option | What It Broadcasts |
|---|---|
| Standard Remote ID | Drone ID, location, altitude, control station location |
| Broadcast Module | Module ID, drone location, takeoff location |
| FRIA | No broadcast required (within designated area only) |

sections.title: Previously Manufactured sUAS
sections.content:
## What the Regulation Says

"Previously manufactured" refers to sUAS produced before certain regulatory requirements took effect.

### Key Points

- Can still be used for **all standard Part 107 operations**
- For Category 4 operations, would need an **airworthiness certificate**
- Can be modified to comply with Category 2/3 requirements
- **Must comply with Remote ID** requirements

### Remote ID Compliance Options

1. Standard Remote ID (if equipped)
2. Add an RID broadcast module
3. Operate within a FRIA

## Key Facts

| Fact | Detail |
|---|---|
| Standard Part 107 operations | **Unaffected** |
| Operations over people | Only if meeting Category 1-4 requirements |
| Remote ID | Must comply via Standard RID, module, or FRIA |
| Category 2/3 path | Must demonstrate compliance through test/analysis/inspection + DoC |
